narrative_events.description: The setting and the protagonist's incarnation are established.

text_span.text: The Bodhisatta was at one time born in the region of Himavanta as a white crane; now Brahmadatta was at that time reigning in Benares.

narrative_events.description: The Lion suffers a physical ailment that prevents him from eating.

text_span.text: Now it chanced that as a lion was eating meat a bone stuck in his throat. The throat became swollen, he could not take food, his suffering was terrible.

narrative_events.description: The Crane offers help conditionally; the Lion promises safety in exchange for the cure.

text_span.text: The crane seeing him, as he was perched on a tree looking for food, asked, "What ails thee, friend?" He told him why. "I could free thee from that bone, friend, but dare not enter thy mouth for fear thou mightest eat me." "Don't be afraid, friend, I'll not eat thee; only save my life.

narrative_events.description: The Crane uses a stick as a safety tool and successfully removes the bone.

text_span.text: he placed a small stick upright between his two jaws that he could not close his mouth, and inserting his head inside his mouth struck one end of the bone with his beak. Whereupon the bone dropped and fell out.

narrative_events.description: The Crane tests the Lion's character by asking for a return favor/gratitude.

text_span.text:
The crane thinking "I will sound him," settled on a branch just over him, and in conversation spoke this first verse:

"A service have we done thee
To the best of our ability,
King of the Beasts! Your Majesty!
What return shall we get from thee?"

narrative_events.description: The Lion refuses to reward the Crane, claiming that sparing the Crane's life is sufficient reward.

text_span.text:
In reply the Lion spoke the second verse:

"As I feed on blood,
And always hunt for prey,
'Tis much that thou art still alive
Having once been between my teeth."

narrative_events.description: The Crane verbally condemns the Lion's ingratitude and leaves to ensure his safety.

text_span.text:
Then in reply the crane said the two other verses:

"Ungrateful, doing no good,
Not doing as he would be done by,
In him there is no gratitude,
To serve him is useless.
"His friendship is not won
By the clearest good deed.
Better softly withdraw from him,
Neither envying nor abusing."
And having thus spoken the crane flew away.

narrative_events.description: The narrator reveals the past-life identities of the characters.

text_span.text: Now at that time the lion was Devadatta the Traitor, but the white crane was I myself.
